title: 112_hr222
content: The "Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011" requires hospitals to implement security procedures for infant patient protection and baby switching to receive Medicare payments. The "Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011" mandates hospitals to have security procedures meeting standards for neonatal and infant care to receive Medicare payments. The "Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011" requires hospitals to implement security procedures to prevent infant abduction and baby switching, meeting standards set by the Secretary of Health and Human Services in consultation with relevant organizations. Regulations will be developed in collaboration with consumer groups, state and local agencies, hospitals, and critical access hospitals, considering variations in size. The "Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011" mandates hospitals to implement security procedures to prevent infant abduction and baby switching. Regulations will be tailored to different hospital sizes and types, with penalties for non-compliance. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must publish these regulations within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The "Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011" requires hospitals participating in the Medicare program to have security procedures in place to prevent infant abduction and baby switching. Hospitals failing to meet these standards face civil money penalties of up to $50,000 (or $25,000 for hospitals with fewer than 100 beds) for each violation. The "Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011" mandates hospitals to implement security measures to prevent infant abduction and baby switching. Hospitals not meeting these standards may incur civil money penalties under section 1128A of the Social Security Act. The effective date for this section is 18 months after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 1205 prohibits baby switching in hospitals under the Infant Protection and Baby Switching Prevention Act of 2011. Whoever alters or destroys a newborn patient's identification record in interstate commerce to misidentify them may face fines up to $250,000 for individuals and $500,000 for organizations, imprisonment up to ten years, or both. The term 'identification record' includes footprints, fingerprints, photographs, written descriptions, and identification bracelets or anklets. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections in chapter 55 of title 18, United States Code, is updated by adding a new item at the end. "1205. Baby switching."
